questions.text: Which of the following is barrier contraception?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Barrier contraception refers to contraceptive methods that physically prevent sperm from reaching and fertilizing an egg. Spermicidal jelly is a type of barrier contraception that contains chemicals (usually nonoxynol-9) designed to immobilize or kill sperm, thus preventing them from reaching the egg.(All other options are ruled out)

Types of barrier contraception

Explanation for other options:

Male sterilization (Option A):

Male sterilization, also known as vasectomy, is a permanent form of contraception that involves surgically blocking or cutting the vas deferens, the tubes that carry sperm from the testes. It is not a barrier contraception method because it does not physically prevent sperm from reaching the egg.

Female sterilization (Option B):

Female sterilization, also known as tubal ligation or tubal sterilization, is a permanent form of contraception that involves blocking or sealing the fallopian tubes to prevent sperm from reaching the egg. While it is an effective contraceptive method, it does not qualify as barrier contraception because it does not physically create a barrier to sperm movement.

Natural (Option D):

"Natural" contraception methods, also known as fertility awareness methods, rely on understanding a woman's menstrual cycle and timing intercourse to avoid fertile days. These methods do not involve physical barriers and are based on tracking ovulation and avoiding intercourse during the fertile window.

Key Takeaways:

  • Barrier or occlusive contraceptive methods have grown in popularity due to both contraceptive and non-contraceptive benefits.
  • Unlike hormonal pills or IUDs, barrier methods typically have fewer side effects. They also offer some protection against sexually transmitted infections, reduce the risk of pelvic inflammatory disease, and may lower the chances of cervical cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following intrauterine contraceptive devices (IUCDs) provides effective contraception for up to 10 years?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cu-T 380A is a type of intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) that is designed to provide contraceptive protection for upto 10 years(All other options are ruled out).
  • It is a T-shaped device made of plastic and wrapped with copper wire (hence the name Cu-T, where Cu stands for copper). The copper acts as a spermicide, preventing sperm from fertilizing the egg.

questions.text: Following intrauterine device (IUD) insertion, which of the following is the most commonly encountered side effect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common side effect of intrauterine device (IUD) insertion is bleeding. This bleeding can occur during or after the insertion procedure. It is normal for women to experience some spotting or light bleeding following IUD insertion.This bleeding may vary in intensity and duration but typically resolves within a few days to weeks.

  • Management of Bleeding in Dysfunctional Uterine Bleeding (DUB): LNG-IUD is the IUCD of choice for treating heavy menstrual bleeding / DUB
  • Contraindication: Copper IUCDs in DUB due to risk of menorrhagia

choices.text: Number of turns of copper wire
Surface area of the entire Cu-T in mm2
Surface area of copper in mm2
Effective life of Cu-T in quarters

questions.text: In Cu-T 380A, the number "380" denotes which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In Cu-T 380-A, the "380" represents the surface area of copper in square millimetres (sq.mm)contained within the device.(All other options are ruled out)

  • Cu-T 380-A is an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUD) that contains copper, which acts as a spermicide to prevent fertilization.
  • This surface area is important because it determines the amount of copper released into the uterine cavity, which contributes to the contraceptive effectiveness of the device.

Key takeaways:

questions.text: Identify the following contraceptive:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gynefix-Cu is considered a fourth-generation intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD). Gynefix-Cu is a frameless, copper-containing IUCD that consists of copper beads threaded on a polypropylene string. It is anchored into the uterine muscle rather than relying solely on uterine cavity adherence, which provides greater flexibility and stability.

Explanation for other options:

a. Essure:

Essure is not an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD); rather, it is a permanent birth control method designed for women who have completed their desired family size. Essure involves the insertion of small, flexible coils into the fallopian tubes, where they induce scar tissue formation, blocking the tubes and preventing fertilization. Therefore, Essure is not a fourth-generation IUCD.

b. Implanon:

Implanon is a contraceptive implant that is inserted sub-dermally (under the skin) in the upper arm. It releases a progestin hormone called etonogestrel to prevent pregnancy for up to three years. Implanon is not an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD), so it does not belong to the category of fourth-generation IUCDs

d. Persona:

Persona is not an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD); rather, it is a fertility monitor used to track hormonal changes in urine samples to identify fertile and non-fertile days in a woman's menstrual cycle.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Progestasert is not true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Progestasert is not implanted sub-dermally; it is actually an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) that is inserted into the uterus

Progestasert:

  • Progestasert is a T-shaped intrauterine device (IUD) made of a flexible plastic material. The T-shaped design helps to anchor the device securely in the uterus and prevents expulsion. (Option D ruled out)
  • Progestasert releases approximately 65 micrograms of progesterone per day into the uterine cavity. (Option A ruled out)
    • This hormone release helps to provide contraception by thickening cervical mucus, inhibiting sperm motility, and thinning the uterine lining.
  • Progestasert contains approximately 38 milligrams of progesterone, which is gradually released over a one-year period to provide contraceptive protection.(Option C ruled out)

choices.text: It is effective for up to 10 years
It has a higher copper content than other IUDs
It has a higher risk of uterine perforation

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the Nova-T intrauterine contraceptive device?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Nova-T is an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUD) that is characterized by its silver core. This silver core serves as a radiopaque marker, which aids in the visualization of the device on X-rays. The presence of the silver core allows healthcare providers to confirm the correct placement of the Nova-T IUD within the uterus during insertion and to monitor its position over time if needed.
  • Its typical duration of effectiveness is around 3 to 5 years (Option A ruled out)
  • Nova-T does not necessarily have more copper content compared to other copper-containing IUDs. The amount of copper in an IUD may vary depending on the specific model and manufacturer. (Option C ruled out)
  • There is no evidence to suggest that Nova-T has a higher likelihood of perforation compared to other IUDs. (Option D ruled out)

choices.text: Has borne at least one child

questions.text: Characteristic of an ideal candidate for copper T insertion include all the following except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Having a history of ectopic pregnancy is not an ideal characteristic for copper T insertion. Women with a history of ectopic pregnancy may have an increased risk of recurrent ectopic pregnancies, which can be life-threatening. Therefore, this characteristic is not considered ideal for IUD insertion.

An ideal candidate for copper T insertion typically meets certain criteria to ensure the safety and effectiveness of the intrauterine device (IUD).

The ideal IUD candidate:

The Planned Parenthood Federation of America (PPFA) has described the ideal IUD candidate as a woman :

  • who has borne at least one child (Option A ruled out)
  • has no history of pelvic disease
  • has normal menstrual periods (Option D ruled out)
  • is willing to check the IUD tail (Option B ruled out)
  • has access to follow-up and treatment of potential problems, and
  • is in a monogamous relationship

questions.text: Which of the following best describes Mala-N?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Mala-N is a combined oral contraceptive pill (COC), which means it contains both an oestrogen and a progestin hormone.Combined pills are commonly used for contraception and are highly effective when taken correctly.
  • It is typically taken daily, with a break of 7 days between packs, although specific dosing instructions may vary depending on the formulation and prescribing healthcare provider's recommendations. (Option D ruled out).

Explanation for other options:

POP pill (Progesterone-only pill) (Option A):

Mala-N is not a progestin-only pill (POP), also known as the minipill. POPs contain only a progestin hormone, without oestrogen. Mala-N, being a combined pill, contains both oestrogen and progestin.

Minipill (Progesterone-only pill) (Option B):

Minipills contain only a progestin hormone, while Mala-N is a combined pill containing both estrogen and progestin.

questions.text: Besides pregnancy, OCP protect against all except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

OCPs have been associated with an increased risk of hepatocellular adenoma, a type of liver tumour. Therefore, they do not protect against this condition. In fact, long-term use of OCPs, particularly those containing oestrogen, has been linked to an increased risk of developing hepatocellular adenomas.

Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) offer various health benefits beyond contraception, but they do not protect against hepatocellular adenoma, a type of liver tumour.

questions.text: Which of the following is/are common side effect(s) associated with the use of oral contraceptive pills (OCPs)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Side Effects of Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs)

Most Common Side Effect: Breakthrough bleeding/spotting during the initial cycles — self-limiting in most users.

1. Common Minor Side Effects

  • Breakthrough bleeding / spotting → due to endometrial instability; resolves with continued use.
  • Breast tenderness & fullness → estrogen causes tenderness; progestogen causes fullness/engorgement.
  • Weight gain → mild (<2 kg in ~25% users), mainly due to water retention; can be reduced with salt restriction.
  • Headache / migraine → may be triggered or worsened; avoid in women with migraine with aura or those on vasoconstrictors like ergotamine.

2. Major Adverse Effects

  • Cardiovascular: ↑ risk of MI, cerebral/venous thrombosis, and pulmonary embolism - especially in smokers >35 years. Estrogen is the main culprit, but progestogen can contribute to vascular effects and hypertension.
  • Carcinogenesis: No confirmed overall increase in cancer risk, but possible ↑ cervical cancer risk with long-term use (under investigation).
  • Metabolic: Hypertension, altered lipid profile (↓ HDL with some progestogens), changes in clotting factors, impaired glucose tolerance - risk is progestogen-dose dependent.
  • Hepatic: Hepatocellular adenoma, gallbladder disease, cholestatic jaundice.

3. Other Considerations

  • Lactation: High-estrogen pills ↓ milk volume (WHO: 42% ↓ with combined pills, 12% with minipills).
  • Fertility: Slight delay in return to fertility (most conceive within months).
  • Ectopic pregnancy: More frequent with progestogen-only pills, not combined pills.
  • Foetal effects: No confirmed teratogenicity, but unproven associations exist.

Exam Rule-Out Strategy:

  • Most common S/E → Breakthrough bleeding (NOT weight gain or breast tenderness).
  • Dangerous S/E → Thromboembolism, MI, stroke (linked to estrogen).
  • Misconception trap: OCPs do not cause permanent infertility.
  • Timing clue: Minor S/E like breast tenderness & bleeding are early; vascular & metabolic risks are long-term.

choices.text: It has been developed in India
It is useful for females with PCOD
Has a Failure rate of 1.83-2.84 per HMY

questions.text: All are true about the following except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Centchroman is primarily used as a contraceptive method for preventing pregnancy and is not specifically indicated for the treatment of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) or polycystic ovary disease (PCOD)
  • Centchroman, also known as Ormeloxifene, is a selective oestrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that acts as a non-hormonal oral contraceptive. It is used for birth control and has several unique characteristics.
  • Centchroman is a nonsteroidal contraceptive. Unlike traditional hormonal contraceptives such as birth control pills, which contain synthetic hormones like oestrogen and progestin, Centchroman works by binding to estrogen receptors in the body, thereby preventing pregnancy without using hormones. (Option A ruled out)
  • Centchroman was developed by the Central Drug Research Institute (CDRI) in Lucknow, India. It was introduced in India under the brand name Saheli and has been available for contraceptive use since the 1990s. (Option B ruled out)
  • The failure rate of Centchroman is reported to be approximately 83 to 2.84 pregnancies per hundred women per year (HMY).This indicates that Centchroman is a relatively effective contraceptive method when used correctly. (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Its mechanism of action is comparable to that of selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs) such as tamoxifen - functioning as a potent estrogen antagonist and a mild estrogen agonist.
  • Contraindicated in women with polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD), as it may further reduce estrogen levels.
  • Commonly referred to in the past as the "once-a-week pill."
  • Dosage regimen: Administered twice weekly for the first three months, followed by once-weekly dosing from the fourth month onward.

questions.text: Which oral contraceptive pill is preferred in lactating women?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The minipill, also known as the progestin-only pill (POP), is typically the preferred choice for lactating women.Progestin-only pills are considered safe for use during breastfeeding because they do not significantly affect milk production or quality.
  • The minipill contains only a progestin hormone and does not contain oestrogen. They are less likely to cause problems with milk supply or composition compared to oestrogen-containing pills. Therefore, the minipill is the OCP of choice for lactating women.

Explanation for other options:

Monophasic (Option A):

  • Monophasic OCPs contain a fixed dose of oestrogen and progestin throughout the entire pill pack. While they are suitable for many women, they are not the preferred choice for lactating women because they contain oestrogen, which can potentially reduce milk production and quality.
  • Oestrogen can also increase the risk of blood clots, which is a concern for breastfeeding women.

Biphasic (Option B):

  • Biphasic OCPs contain two different doses of hormones during the pill cycle. Like monophasic pills, they contain estrogen, making them less suitable for lactating women due to the concerns mentioned above.

Triphasic (Option C):

  • Triphasic OCPs contain three different doses of hormones during the pill cycle, typically changing every seven days. While triphasic pills may provide more closely mimicked hormonal fluctuations compared to monophasic or biphasic pills, they still contain oestrogen and are not generally recommended for lactating women.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used as an emergency contraceptive method?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Emergency contraceptive measures are methods used to prevent pregnancy after unprotected intercourse or contraceptive failure. Female condoms are not typically used as emergency contraception. While female condoms provide a barrier method of contraception, they are designed for use before intercourse to prevent sperm from entering the vagina and reaching the egg. They are not intended for use after unprotected intercourse to prevent pregnancy. Therefore, they are not considered an emergency contraceptive measure.

Explanation for other options:

b. Mini pill (progestin-only pill):

  • The mini pill, or progestin-only pill (POP), can be used as an emergency contraceptive
  • If taken within a specific timeframe after unprotected intercourse, typically within 72 hours but up to 120 hours in some cases, the mini pill can help prevent pregnancy by thickening cervical mucus, inhibiting ovulation, and altering the endometrium to prevent implantation of a fertilized egg.

c. IUD (Intrauterine Device):

  • The intrauterine device (IUD) can be used as an emergency contraceptive
  • Copper IUDs, such as the Copper T IUD, can be inserted into the uterus within a specific timeframe after unprotected intercourse to prevent pregnancy. Copper IUDs work by releasing copper ions, which are toxic to sperm and prevent fertilization. They can also prevent implantation of a fertilized egg.

d. Yuzpe and Lancee regimen: Both are emergency contraceptives

questions.text: DOC for emergency contraception
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Levonorgestrel-only pills contain a progestin hormone (levonorgestrel 0.75mg) and are specifically formulated for use as emergency contraception. They are highly effective at preventing pregnancy when taken within a specific timeframe after unprotected intercourse, typically within 72 hours but up to 120 hours in some cases.

Levonorgestrel-only pills work primarily by preventing ovulation and may also affect sperm motility and fertilization.

They are considered safe and well-tolerated, with fewer side effects compared to the Yuzpe regimen or high-dose oestrogen (1.5 mg single dose OR 0.75 mg × 2 doses, 12 hrs apart)

Emergency contraception (EC) refers to methods used to prevent pregnancy after unprotected intercourse or contraceptive failure. Levonorgestrel-only pills (LNG-only pills), commonly known as "morning-after pills" or "emergency contraceptive pills (ECPs)", are the drug of choice (DOC) for emergency contraception.

Explanation for other options:

a. Yuzpe Regimen:

  • The Yuzpe regimen involves taking high doses of combined oral contraceptive pills (COCs) containing both oestrogen and progestin within a specific timeframe after unprotected intercourse.
  • While it was previously a common method of emergency contraception, it is now considered less effective and has more side effects compared to dedicated ECPs. Therefore, it is no longer recommended as the DOC for emergency contraception.
  • Dosage: 100 µg ethinylestradiol + 0.5 mg levonorgestrel. Repeat same dose after 12 hours

b. High dose oestrogen:

High-dose oestrogen was previously used in combination with progestin in the Yuzpe regimen for emergency contraception. However, it is associated with more side effects and less efficacy compared to dedicated emergency contraceptive pills such as LNG-only pills. Therefore, it is not the preferred choice for emergency contraception.

d. Danazol:

Danazol is not used for emergency contraception. It is a synthetic steroid hormone that has antiestrogenic effects and is primarily used to treat conditions such as endometriosis and fibrocystic breast disease. It is not indicated or effective for emergency contraception.

questions.text: Which of the following can be used as an emergency contraceptive?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Emergency contraception (EC) refers to methods used to prevent pregnancy after unprotected intercourse or contraceptive failure.All the above mentioned options are used as an emergency contraceptive.

Indications for Emergency Contraception:

  • Unprotected sexual intercourse
  • Sexual assault / rape
  • Condom breakage or slippage

Timing of Administration:

  • Ideal: Within 72 hours (maximum efficacy)
  • Can be given: Up to 120 hours after intercourse (reduced efficacy)

questions.text: All the following are true about menstrual regulation except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Menstrual regulation is not the same as abortion.

Menstrual regulation is a procedure performed to regulate menstruation and prevent the establishment of pregnancy, typically in the early stages after a missed period. It aims to remove the uterine lining and any potential fertilized egg without the intention of terminating an established pregnancy.

Abortion, on the other hand, is a procedure performed to terminate an established pregnancy.

Menstrual Regulation (MR):

  • It is a fertility control method used within 14 days of a missed period to ensure a woman is not pregnant or does not remain pregnant - before confirmation of pregnancy.(Option B ruled out)
  • The most common method is vacuum aspiration using a flexible cannula, often without anesthesia or cervical dilation.
  • Timing of Procedure:
    • Ideally performed within 14 days of a missed period(Option A ruled out).
    • Higher efficiency and lower complication rates when done ≤14 days after the missed period.
  • Efficacy & Efficiency:
    • Failure rate: ~0.7% among confirmed pregnant women.
    • Efficiency depends on performing MR in women likely to be pregnant.
  • In settings where MR is legally allowed, it can be performed without facing legal restrictions or penalties. However, legal restrictions may vary by country, and access to MR may be limited in some regions.(Option C ruled out)

questions.text: Identify the contraceptive device shown in the image. How long can this device be left in place before removal is recommended?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image depicts a vaginal ring, also known as the contraceptive ring or NuvaRing, is a hormonal contraceptive method that is inserted into the vagina to prevent pregnancy.

questions.text: Following vasectomy, alternative contraceptive methods should be continued until:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Vasectomy is a surgical procedure for male sterilization where the vas deferens, the tubes that carry sperm from the testicles to the urethra, are cut, tied, or sealed. While vasectomy is an effective form of permanent contraception, it takes time for the procedure to become fully effective i.e. 8 weeks. (Option C ruled out)
  • It is generally recommended that patients use alternative methods of contraception, such as condoms, for at least eight weeks or until they have undergone post-vasectomy semen analysis (PVSA) to confirm the absence of sperm in their ejaculate. It can take several ejaculations and a period of time for any remaining sperm to be cleared from the reproductive system after vasectomy.
  • Therefore, waiting at least eight weeks or until PVSA indicates no sperm is present provides a more reliable indication of contraceptive effectiveness.

Explanation for other options:

a. Removal of all sutures:

While the removal of sutures is an important step in the healing process after vasectomy, it does not indicate the time when the procedure becomes fully effective in preventing pregnancy. Patients may still have viable sperm in their semen immediately after the procedure, so relying solely on the removal of sutures as a marker for effectiveness would not be appropriate.

b. Pain relieved:

Pain relief after vasectomy does not correlate with the effectiveness of the procedure in preventing pregnancy. Pain can subside relatively quickly after the procedure, but viable sperm may still be present in the ejaculate until the vas deferens have been completely cleared of sperm.

questions.text: What is the prevalence of emergency contraceptive use per 100 population in India?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Emergency contraception (EC) is a method of contraception that can be used to prevent pregnancy after unprotected sexual intercourse or contraceptive failure.

  • In India, the availability and use of emergency contraception vary across regions and populations.
  • However, estimates suggest that the prevalence of emergency contraception per 100 population falls within the range of 150 to 180.
    • This range represents a more plausible estimate for the prevalence of emergency contraception per 100 population in India.
    • This range suggests a moderate to high prevalence of emergency contraception, reflecting its importance in preventing unintended pregnancies and supporting reproductive autonomy.

Key takeaways:

Indications for Emergency Contraception:

  • Unprotected sexual intercourse
  • Sexual assault / rape
  • Condom breakage or slippage

Timing of Administration:

  • Ideal: Within 72 hours (maximum efficacy)
  • Can be given: Up to 120 hours after intercourse (reduced efficacy)

choices.text: From 12 hrs to 7 days of delivery
From 24 hrs to 7 days of delivery
From 48 hrs to 7 days of delivery

questions.text: Ideal time to perform post-partum sterilisation
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Postpartum sterilization, also known as postpartum tubal ligation, is a surgical procedure to permanently prevent pregnancy, typically performed immediately after childbirth Postpartum sterilization is ideally performed within 24 hours to 7 days after delivery. The ideal timing for postpartum sterilization is crucial for ensuring safety and effectiveness while minimizing risks associated with the procedure.

  • Timing:. This timeframe allows for the procedure to be conducted during the same hospital admission as childbirth, minimizing the need for additional hospital visits and anaesthesia administration.
  • Safety: Performing the procedure within 24 hours to 7 days of delivery reduces the risk of complications associated with surgery. The uterus is still enlarged, making it easier for the surgeon to access the fallopian tubes for ligation. Additionally, the patient is usually still under medical supervision, which ensures prompt management of any potential complications.
  • Convenience: Performing postpartum sterilization during the same hospital admission as childbirth provides convenience for the patient. It eliminates the need for a separate hospital visit and recovery period, allowing the patient to recover from both procedures simultaneously.

questions.text: Installation of condom vending machines at petrol pumps is an example of
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Condom vending machines at petrol pumps exemplify the concept of social marketing. Social marketing involves using marketing principles and techniques to promote products, services, or behaviours that benefit society. In the context of public health, social marketing aims to influence people's attitudes, beliefs, and behaviours to improve health outcomes.

Explanation for other options:

Appropriate technology (Option B):

While condom vending machines may utilize appropriate technology in their design and operation, the primary focus is on the marketing aspect rather than the technology itself. Appropriate technology typically refers to technologies that are suitable for the environmental, social, and economic conditions of a specific community or context.

Socialization (OptionC):

Socialization refers to the process by which individuals acquire social norms, values, and behaviours through interactions with others and social institutions such as family, school, and media. The term "socialization" does not fully capture the marketing aspect involved in promoting condom use through vending machines

Community participation (Option D):

Community participation involves engaging community members in decision-making processes and activities that affect their lives. While the installation of condom vending machines may be part of broader public health initiatives that involve community input, the primary focus of condom vending machines is on making condoms accessible through commercial channels rather than directly involving communities in decision-making or implementation

questions.text: In a subcentre, an ANM covers 400 families with an average of 5 members per family, and the CBR is 20 per 1000 population. What is the minimum expected number of pregnancies to be registered with the ANM?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The minimum expected number of pregnancies to be registered with the ANM in this scenario is 40.

Crude Birth Rate

  • Defined as the number of live births per 1000 estimated mid-year population in a given year.
  • Formula:

Given:

  • Number of families = 400
  • Average family size = 5
  • CBR = 20 per 1000 population

Total population covered by ANM

  • Total population = 400×5 = 2000

Expected number of births (CBR formula)

Therefore, the minimum expected number of pregnancies is 40.

questions.text: In emergency contraception, administration of 0.75 mg levonorgestrel should be followed by
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In emergency contraception, the 0.75mg levonorgestrel pill is typically taken as a single dose. It is considered a progestin-only emergency contraceptive pill (sometimes referred to as the "morning-after pill").
  • This pill works by preventing or delaying ovulation, thereby reducing the likelihood of pregnancy if taken within a specific timeframe after unprotected intercourse.
  • This follow-up regimen involves taking another dose of the same 0.75mg levonorgestrel pill approximately 12 hours after the first dose.
  • This regimen is commonly recommended to enhance the effectiveness of emergency contraception, as taking a second dose helps to maintain adequate levels of the hormone in the body over a longer period, further inhibiting ovulation and reducing the risk of pregnancy.

questions.text: WHO-recommended single-dose regimen of Levonorgestrel (LNG) for emergency contraception is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends a specific dosage of levonorgestrel (LNG) for use in emergency contraceptives. It is a single dose of 1.5 mg of levonorgestrel taken as soon as possible after unprotected intercourse, ideally within 72 hours (3 days) but can be effective up to 120 hours (5 days) after intercourse.
